story:
Featured on:

Rock Paper Shotgun | Eurogamer | PC Gamer | Indiegames.com | Cliqist 

 

Please note that this campaign is no longer accepting funds. The game will be released on Steam, Humble Store and itch.io on 3rd February 2017.

Perks selected will not be valid if you are contributing after November 5th 2016. But thanks for your support! Why not visit the Steam page and put the game on your wishlist instead?

 

| Twitter | Website | Dev Blog |

 

 

 

"I scuttle nervously into the darkness. I've been commissioned to write an article on current affairs in the Chimeric Empire. I suppose if some horrific event befalls me, I can use it as fodder for my next poem. Provided I survive..."

A House of Many Doors is a 2D exploration RPG coming to PC in July next year. I want to make the kind of game I love to play: a game with narrative depth, compelling characters, and branching, nonlinear storylines.

In A House of Many Doors you are an explorer, poet and spy, traversing and mapping the House – a vast parasite dimension that steals from other worlds.

You explore the House in a clanking train with mechanical legs. You will discover bizarre civilizations, assemble a dysfunctional crew and level up your poetry, while clinging to life and sanity.

I've already spent nine eleven months developing A House of Many Doors, so I have a good idea of how much longer I need to complete it. The bulk of the programming is done, and the blueprints have been drawn. Now I just need time to build a House on that foundation.

My influences include Sunless Sea, FTL, Planescape: Torment, the works of China Mieville and H.P. Lovecraft, Italo Calvino's Invisible Cities, and that feeling you get when you're very alone in a big dark house.

 

In A House of Many Doors, your main quest is to find an answer to one of three questions. What is the House's purpose? Who built it? And how can you escape?

But that's just the main quest, and it's only the beginning. Your irons will be in many fires.

I want you to feel like a particular type of 19th-century polymath - a Richard Francis Burton or a Gertrude Bell. An absurd figure with absurd talents who propels themselves confidently into absurdly terrifying situations. 

In the game you are both a journalist and a poet, and each of those careers comes with its own challenges to face throughout the game. The poems you write are procedurally-generated, and over time you will build up a proud canon of stirring titles: "The Troglodyte Vomiting of the Mirrors," "An Elegy on the Reluctant Hell of Grief," "Ode to the Strangling Toad." Your poems and travelogues are your route to fame and fortune.

 

And of course anyone who travels to distant civilizations is going to be in high demand in the game of whispers. Play the espionage game well enough, and you might change the course of history.

 

 As you explore the House, you will journey through a labyrinth of procedurally-generated architecture. 

 It's not all procedural generation, though - your Navigator will guide you towards rooms in which you'll discover carefully-designed areas of interactive narrative. 

These rooms are packed with quests, stories and lore - by "lore" I mean the House's intricate history, ancient secrets and complex politics, much of which will lurk below the surface and only be revealed in hints and half-truths. In these cavernous rooms you might find cities or ruins or ten-mile-high abomination gods made of inexpertly conjoined crows. 

The adventures you'll have there are accompanied by the wonderful artwork of Catherine Unger. 

In these rooms you tackle side-quests, gather resources, and plot intrigues before launching yourself once more into the dark.

 

A House of Many Doors focuses heavily on its characters. You recruit a rag-tag bunch of dysfunctional souls to accompany you on your expedition, and each of them has a secret or not-so-secret agenda. You must talk to them, build their morale, and uncover their secrets, if you hope to keep them both loyal and alive.

There will be dozens of characters to choose from, each with tons of dialogue and a well-defined arc - which can be abruptly cut short.

Death comes easy in the House, and the attachments you have formed with your crew will be at risk every time you fight. A character's storyline won't necessarily end if they're killed in combat, but it will certainly change to reflect their death. And you may well have lost a friend.

 

Combat is a real-time-with-pause system which relies on careful management of both your crew's placement in the train and the distance between you and the enemy. 

It is generally a last resort - even after upgrading your kinetopede with powerful weapons and a thick hull, you should never expect to escape a battle unscathed. 

The other vehicles you encounter within the House will be as bizarre and varied as the civilizations themselves - biomechanical flesh-wagons, gigantic beetles, the hollowed corpses of gods. That's just the start.

I'm seeding the House with dozens and dozens of hand-designed rooms - gems of narrative carefully scattered through a procedurally-generated world. The game is currently able to generate over 1 million rooms, each of them unique, but the hand-designed rooms risk getting lost if the number available is not limited. So, on release, there will be approximately 40,000 rooms to explore. This limit not only leads to a balanced experience, but also means I have the ability to add more rooms with ease. Unless the game fails this Kickstarter, or is a total commercial failure, I plan to continue to add new rooms and settings to the House as new ideas come to me.  

The game you play on release will be a complete game. But new content will constantly be added. New places to discover. New characters. Established content will be deepened. More and more branches will be added to existing storylines.

For £5 now, you could have access to a game that will continue growing for years to come. And of course, I'll maintain my dev log all the while!

Risks & Challenges

Here are the main risks or problems I can foresee:

1) Feature Creep. If the game is commercially successful, I want to continue to update the game with free content, 'expanding' the House after release. But I mustn't do this during the development process! ‘Feature creep' is a notorious problem in game development, and if I fall prey to it I might slip behind schedule. The fact that I'm aware of this risk will help to mitigate it - I just need to ensure that I stick to my plans, which are already ambitious enough.

2) Data Loss. Losing data to corruption, burglary, or some other minor disaster has the potential to set the project back a great deal. To mitigate this risk, I’m making regular back-ups online, as well as regular back-ups to a laptop and 4 different external USB devices.

3) Compatibility. I've been testing the game on various different machines, from gaming rigs to laptops, and I've already found several problems only appearing on one machine that I've had to iron out. Towards the end of the development cycle, this could end up eating a lot more of my time than anticipated. To mitigate this risk, I've allotted a very generous period of time for facing this challenge in my schedule.

story:
We Want Linux to be a First-Class Citizen for Game Development

Right now, Linux has some great programming libraries for developing games, but when it comes to working as a level designer or an artist, the tools are lagging behind Windows and Mac OS X. It’s not from lack of trying. There are great developers working on tools day and night for Linux, but the going is slow. Unity announced an export option for their engine so that game developers on Mac and Windows can export to Linux. This is EXCELLENT news for Linux game players. It’s the same news as always for Linux game developers: to make games: buy a Mac or pay for Windows if you want to make games.

We started this campaign to change that message. We want Linux to be a first-class citizen for game developers. We recently open sourced Torque 3D under the MIT license, and the first deluge of questions were about Linux compatibility. The move to open source Torque was something that the founders of GarageGames wanted to do over 10 years ago, but they also needed a business model for their studio.

Torque is the engine that was originally used in the Tribes series of games, and has seen a number of advancements throughout its history. Since open sourcing it, we have had nearly 300 forks of the codebase on GitHub. You can find out more information about Torque at the GarageGames site and download it from GitHub to kick the tires. Unfortunately, it’s only for Windows right now, so you might have to flex your Wine or dual-booting muscles to try it out.

What’s In It for All of Us?

We want a dedicated Linux-native game development platform. We don’t think that Linux game developers should have to switch between machines so that they can develop on Windows and just test on Linux. We don’t think that they should have to fiddle with Wine to get the simplest of editors to work natively, only to have the whole thing crash when importing models. We want Linux to be a native platform for game developers.

Workflow for Engines without Native Support

If you use any of the popular engines out there that have Linux support, here is a workflow (assuming dual-booting).

Open editor. Import models, edit level, add logic, etc. Build the game. Export to Linux. Copy the binary to a shared drive. Reboot and load Linux. Copy from the shared drive locally. Run the game. Crash. Get crash report. Copy crash report to shared drive. Reboot. Load engine and crash report. Find mistake and attempt to repair. Repeat.

This loop is a little faster if you have two computers next to each other and a shared device, but even then you’re switching gears and doing a lot of waiting. Waiting means that you have time to get coffee or check Slashdot for news, but it’s also time that you could be making your game.

Our Solution: Linux-Native Game Development


Obvious, right? Well, it should be. But it’s also an answer that takes a lot of time and money to implement. When commercial software companies look at their bottom line, the return on investment for developing software for Linux is really low (and often unknown) in the game engine development world. John Carmack noted during his keynote at QuakeCon that “Valve announcing Steam Linux support changes things a bit but we have made two forays into Linux commercial market, most recently with Quake Live client but that platform just hasn't carried its weight compared to Mac” (45:26, QuakeCon 2012 - John Carmack Keynote). This was specifically about game targets, but the lack of commercial editor support for game development on Linux speaks volumes on how the engine industry feels about Linux.

Luckily, our platform layer has some of the core functionality needed for a Linux port. Our dedicated server has been used on Linux for a number of years with different games, and that handles much of the core engine functionality. What currently is not working on Linux is the game editor and shared client. That’s where you come in.

So, How Will the Money be Used?

Well, this is an experiment to see if crowd funding can pay for specific features that people really want in a game engine.

What we are asking for is enough money, based on a number of estimates from strong Linux developers who have ported large codebases in the past, to make this port happen. The estimates were between two and three months for a single, dedicated developer. We chose three months to accommodate any found-work that can come up. As software developers, we know that once you start down a path, new work will be discovered, so we wanted to make sure to include a buffer for it.

The project will pay $45 an hour for roughly 3 months worth of work from a single developer (a team can be hired to increase productivity, but there will be a finite amount of money from the campaign to pay them). Of course, IndieGoGo will get 4% off the top for hosting the service. The payment providers (credit cards, PayPal, etc) will get roughly 3-4% depending on international fees, etc. Then, the prize tiers will be fulfilled, shirts and such bought and shipped! The remainder of the money will go towards the development team porting Torque 3D to Linux.

When Will We See Updates?

As it is developed. That’s right. Torque 3D is open source and up on Github right now. You can download it and take it to town, kick the tires, and see what it’s all about. There will also be a Linux branch live on GitHub where you can watch the developers porting the engine to Linux. You get to see the benefits immediately. You do not have to wait a long time watching for infrequent updates, hoping to see something in a year or two. You will have full access to the development branch of the Linux port to see the team’s progress, commit by commit.

But even if we do not reach our goal, and your money goes right back in your pockets, we think you’ll see a Linux port eventually. It just won’t be nearly as quick since the developers have jobs, families, bills, and they’re doing the port of a very large engine in their limited free time. Why not hire them so that the port can be their full-time job? That’s what we want to do.

Our first platform target is 32b Ubuntu, with stretch goals for other platforms to be announced.

I love Linux, but have no money! How can I help?

  • Tell people. Tell your friends and family, local installfests, anyone who would love to make games on Linux.
  • Share this project using the IndieGoGo social tools, your favorite social media platforms, or just by linking to it on forums that you frequent!
  • Leave comments so that we can answer your questions.

UPDATE 1 - Frozen Synapse and New Tiers!

Well, we certainly hope that everyone had a great holiday season and are enjoying the start of a new year! Over the break, we tossed around a couple of ideas on how to make our Torque 3D for Linux campaign even better. We took the advice of people here and out and about on the internet and we received a very strong endorsement from Mode 7 Games.

One of the great things about creating game development technology for as long as we have, is that we have some amazing developers who have created absolutely amazing games with our tech. Mode 7 Games is one of those development teams. Their game, Frozen Synapse, won the audience choice award at the Independent Games Festival and the 2011 strategy game of the year from PC Gamer. It is also available on Steam for Linux since their top-notch team did the port themselves.

Paul Taylor had this to say about their company and Torque on Linux:
“Torque has been essential to our success as an indie development studio: its flexibility coupled with its power means that it is the ideal platform for Mode 7.

Through our experience with Humble Bundle and now with Valve’s Steam for Linux, we’ve found that there is a thriving market for indie games on Linux. We would love to get more directly involved with our own Linux versions: Torque for Linux would allow us to do this.

The success of this fundraising drive would make a huge difference to us and a host of other indie developers. We’re happy to provide copies of Frozen Synapse as an incentive for you to support this important project."

They are generously donating copies of Frozen Synapse to anyone who pledges $25 or more to the Torque 3D for Linux campaign.

In other news, we’re opening three new tiers and removing the $10,000 tier.

The first two tiers are an hour of dedicated support with Eric or I (or the appropriate GarageGames employee). We will provide dedicated support on game development problems, Torque-specific issues, business development strategies, real-time optimization techniques, profiling resources, code analysis, or whatever help you really need to finish your game. My tier is $100 and Eric’s is $250.

The next tier that we are adding is $7000 and includes a trip to Vegas, dinner with a number of GarageGames employees, and a five-star hotel stay here. We have to restrict this tier to residents of the US and Canada or the international flight costs would eat up any money that will go to the Linux developers doing the port.

Video Update!

Go to the update page to watch the video update and meet some of the team here at GarageGames!

About Torque

Torque 3D is based on the 2007 Frontline award winning Torque Game Engine Advanced. It has been actively developed for over ten years, beginning its life at Dynamix for the Starseige Tribes games. After the closure of Dynamix by Sierra On-Line, some of the studio formed GarageGames with the vision of changing the way games are made and played.

About GarageGames

GarageGames is a 3D visualization middleware company dedicated to creating top-tier technology for the game and simulation industries. GarageGames has over seventy years of combined experience and a successful engine platform for the last 10 years.

We Want Linux to be a First-Class Citizen for Game Development
Right now, Linux has some great programming libraries for developing games, but when it comes to working as a level designer or an artist, the tools are lagging behind Windows and Mac OS X. It’s not from lack of trying. There are great developers working on tools day and night for Linux, but the going is slow. Unity announced an export option for their engine so that game developers on Mac and Windows can export to Linux. This is EXCELLENT news for Linux game players. It’s the same news as always for Linux game developers: to make games: buy a Mac or pay for Windows if you want to make games.We started this campaign to change that message. We want Linux to be a first-class citizen for game developers. We recently open sourced Torque 3D under the MIT license, and the first deluge of questions were about Linux compatibility. The move to open source Torque was something that the founders of GarageGames wanted to do over 10 years ago, but they also needed a business model for their studio.Torque is the engine that was originally used in the Tribes series of games, and has seen a number of advancements throughout its history. Since open sourcing it, we have had nearly 300 forks of the codebase on GitHub. You can find out more information about Torque at the GarageGames site and download it from GitHub to kick the tires. Unfortunately, it’s only for Windows right now, so you might have to flex your Wine or dual-booting muscles to try it out.

What’s In It for All of Us?
We want a dedicated Linux-native game development platform. We don’t think that Linux game developers should have to switch between machines so that they can develop on Windows and just test on Linux. We don’t think that they should have to fiddle with Wine to get the simplest of editors to work natively, only to have the whole thing crash when importing models. We want Linux to be a native platform for game developers.

Workflow for Engines without Native Support
If you use any of the popular engines out there that have Linux support, here is a workflow (assuming dual-booting).
Open editor. Import models, edit level, add logic, etc. Build the game. Export to Linux. Copy the binary to a shared drive. Reboot and load Linux. Copy from the shared drive locally. Run the game. Crash. Get crash report. Copy crash report to shared drive. Reboot. Load engine and crash report. Find mistake and attempt to repair. Repeat.This loop is a little faster if you have two computers next to each other and a shared device, but even then you’re switching gears and doing a lot of waiting. Waiting means that you have time to get coffee or check Slashdot for news, but it’s also time that you could be making your game.
Our Solution: Linux-Native Game Development
Obvious, right? Well, it should be. But it’s also an answer that takes a lot of time and money to implement. When commercial software companies look at their bottom line, the return on investment for developing software for Linux is really low (and often unknown) in the game engine development world. John Carmack noted during his keynote at QuakeCon that “Valve announcing Steam Linux support changes things a bit but we have made two forays into Linux commercial market, most recently with Quake Live client but that platform just hasn't carried its weight compared to Mac” (45:26, QuakeCon 2012 - John Carmack Keynote). This was specifically about game targets, but the lack of commercial editor support for game development on Linux speaks volumes on how the engine industry feels about Linux.Luckily, our platform layer has some of the core functionality needed for a Linux port. Our dedicated server has been used on Linux for a number of years with different games, and that handles much of the core engine functionality. What currently is not working on Linux is the game editor and shared client. That’s where you come in.

So, How Will the Money be Used?
Well, this is an experiment to see if crowd funding can pay for specific features that people really want in a game engine.
What we are asking for is enough money, based on a number of estimates from strong Linux developers who have ported large codebases in the past, to make this port happen. The estimates were between two and three months for a single, dedicated developer. We chose three months to accommodate any found-work that can come up. As software developers, we know that once you start down a path, new work will be discovered, so we wanted to make sure to include a buffer for it.The project will pay $45 an hour for roughly 3 months worth of work from a single developer (a team can be hired to increase productivity, but there will be a finite amount of money from the campaign to pay them). Of course, IndieGoGo will get 4% off the top for hosting the service. The payment providers (credit cards, PayPal, etc) will get roughly 3-4% depending on international fees, etc. Then, the prize tiers will be fulfilled, shirts and such bought and shipped! The remainder of the money will go towards the development team porting Torque 3D to Linux.

As it is developed. That’s right. Torque 3D is open source and up on Github right now. You can download it and take it to town, kick the tires, and see what it’s all about. There will also be a Linux branch live on GitHub where you can watch the developers porting the engine to Linux. You get to see the benefits immediately. You do not have to wait a long time watching for infrequent updates, hoping to see something in a year or two. You will have full access to the development branch of the Linux port to see the team’s progress, commit by commit.But even if we do not reach our goal, and your money goes right back in your pockets, we think you’ll see a Linux port eventually. It just won’t be nearly as quick since the developers have jobs, families, bills, and they’re doing the port of a very large engine in their limited free time. story:
The Game

Finally a fashion game that's not for little girls. This is no cute 'dress-up' game. This is a faithful and realistic simulator for those who are truly serious and passionate about the fashion industry.

"Fashion Designer Pro" lets you create your own brand, research the current trends, design your collection, manufacture enough units, present them at fashion shows, open up international markets, and distribute your product.

It is a simulator/management game targeted for mobile platforms in the lines of Game Dev Story and other 'Tycoon' style business management games.

The game will firstly be available on Android, although our supporters (Fashionista Brass or above) will have access to an exclusive PC/Mac version on top of that! It is in our best interest to publish it on iPhone and iPad, but it will depend on Apple's end.

The Team

The core of the team is a combination of skilled game developers and veteran fashion consultants that will keep the project realistic and true to it's spirit.

It's a family run project, so it's nice and tight. For better or for worse, no one is dropping out!

Alain Xalabarde

The main guy behind the project is me, Alain. I've been a filmmaker since the age of 13 and a game designer since the age of 16.

Both my parents are veteran fashion designers, so I've grown surrounded by fashion all my life. It was a matter of time for both worlds to click.

I will be in charge principally of game design. Although I will also be partaking in graphic design, writing, producing and basically wherever I'm needed.

You can check out my gamer site at www.AlineGames.com or my filmmaker site at www.Xalabarde.com

Klara Guillen

Klara has been a fashion teacher, she has created numerous luxury collections, and has constantly been supporting young fashion designers. She alone has over 30 years experience in the industry and is an extremely active, strong and independent woman overall. And I'm not just saying that because she's my mom.

She keeps the game fidelity in track when it comes to designing and manufacturing clothes. She knows exactly what products are needed, what clients seek, and how to deliver it successfully.

Also, she's my mom.

You may visit her site at www.KlaraGuillen.com

Inaki Xalabarde

Inaki has worked in the leather goods industry in companies from South Africa, Spain and United States, including top brands such as Coach (#1 in the US). He is a true craftsman in every sense of the word.

He is the numbers guy. He knows every trend cycle, what materials are best used for which collections, which markets are the strongest choice for your product, how to economize your production line, and pretty much any overlooked facts on the reality of this industry.

Also, he's my dad.

You?

We will, of course, include many others in our team as things get more complex. For the time being, I could manage on my own, but I'll eventually need to hire artists, musicians, coders, etc. If you think you'd make a great addition to the team, don't hesitate to contact us!

The Project

The idea for the game started more than a year ago when I was visiting my parents. I was between jobs and had time on my hands, so I decided to work on a new game to keep me busy.

What began as a mere experiment became and increasingly exciting reality. This game was awesome! Unfortunately (or fortunately) I found a job and I couldn't invest as much time as I'd like on the game.

I find myself, once again, between jobs, and an opportunity is presented to me: "Why not get a full-time job making this game?".

Where would the funds go?

Funds are mainly required to hire external art, purchase music licenses, acquire needed software or plugins, etc. Part of it will also be used to promote the game and build a fan base for it. This will help us find an interested publisher that can give the game's distribution that extra push.

Mainly though, the funds are so that I can spend more time actually making the game! The principal problem until now has been having to work on it for a couple of days, letting it go for weeks (in order to work so I could pay for my food), forgetting most of the stuff I did, getting back to it, trying to figure out where I left off... you see where this is going. Part of the funds will be used a salary so that I can develop the game full-time.

You're basically becoming my bosses: hiring me to finally complete the game!

The depth of the final product will therefore depend on how much is eventually funded (in other words, how long I can invest on it depends on the budget limit). The minimum we need to make a complete running game is 5000 euro, so if we raise less than that, the project will be put on stand-by and you will receive your money back.

The Fashionistas (supporters)

What is so awesome about becoming a supporter? Well, firstly, you can make your friends call you an official "Fashionista". How cool is that?

Secondly, you'll be part of a fashion game! Starting from, having a credit as the one who believed in it, followed it from the beginning and made it happen! So much so that you can even get your name to be, literally, part of the game. Your name can appear in the game as a random name! That's not all. I bet a lot of times you've wondered how video games are made. Now you can live it step by step with Beta Zone.

What is Beta Zone?

Beta Zone is the place where you can become part of the making of the game itself! You can play updated demos and give your feedback straight from your own personal account on our site. You will follow it every step of the way and be able to experience it as it is being made!

It'll be like having a baby you don't have to take care of, play with it, and watch it grow!

Find out more on our official site: www.FashionDesignerPro.com

FAQ

Why is iPhone & iPad not guaranteed?

Android is a lot more open when it comes to user-created content, whereas Apple has strict norms and approval procedures. It is in our interest to 

How much will the retail price of the game be?

Our supporters (10 euros or above) have access to the game for free. As for the retail price to the general public, we are heading towards a modest price of around 99 cents. This price is just an expectation, but it's not fixed and it may vary depending on the project's evolution.

Why use Construct 2 to develop the game?

As I mentioned before, I am a Game Designer, with skills in graphic design. I have very little knowledge of coding. With other methods, I'd have to hire external coders to develop the game, which would increase the budget exponentially, having to sacrifice many of the game's features along the way.

Since it's a 2D game for mobile platforms, Construct 2 gives me the opportunity to make this indie game truly independent. I don't rely on others to finish it off. I've been using Construct 2 and similar software for years, and it is a great tool for this sort of 'relatively small' projects.

story:
UPDATE NOTES:

I just posted a couple more video links in the gallery section showing a couple more of my very latest editing examples (including the AEG Coils of Madness trailer) for the editing perks.

Funding Contest

IndieGoGo Funding Contest: If we are fully funded, The person that get's the most funding for us will win at least $800 Store credit. Second Place $200 Store Credit and Third Place $50 Store Credit! Just log onto IndieGogo, copy the link registered to your name from the indieGogo site and spread it around (in a non spammer manner)! For anyone not local to the store and they win the contest there will be no shipping costs. For every $5,000 we exceed our goal we will add another 10% to each of the store credit amounts. The only rules is no blatant spamming which would include random mass emailing and automation. 

Short Summary

My Name is Ron Petersen and I started planning The Gamer's Grind back in early 2010. Funded with a small inheritance, our doors opened in March 2012. My intention was to use the tools left to me to build something unique and provide some much needed entertainment to our local community: a board game café!

What qualifies me to take on something so ambitious? I'm glad you asked.

I have a diverse background in retail and distributor sales as well as running a small business. I have experience with shipping and receiving, video production, working in the media. But most of all, I have a passion for people and games.

In researching our business plan I discovered a place called Snakes and Lattes that had just opened in Toronto Canada. They've enjoyed great success, doubling their store's size and acquiring a liquor license. Their success shows us that the board game café model clearly works.

Our Mission and Vision

Our mission is to provide the ultimate game night experience. We believe every type of game is valuable and can bring friends and family together to share laughs and enjoy each other’s company. We intend to keep building up the wall of games to have an extensive library. We want every type of gamer to have a large variety of options to choose from in a comfortable and fun environment, even the pickiest of game enthusiasts. Our mission is also to open people's eyes to just how many games are out there. The more casual or occasional game player may only be aware of what one or two large corporations have to offer, but the game palette we offer is much more varied. But most importantly we want to offer a highly unique entertainment destination. This is still a new business model in North America, and that’s what makes it such a great opportunity!

What is a Board Game Café?

Board Game Cafes have been around for a while and are very popular in many Asian countries and some European countries, but hardly any exist in North America. Basically you take a café or coffee house, combine it with a large library of games to play, and throw in a small game store. People come in, pay a small amount and can play games as long as they like while enjoying the available food, snacks, and drinks. Some board game cafes charge by the hour, but we opted for a cover charge instead because we believe it’s more conducive to a relaxing and casual environment. It’s proven successful with Snakes and Lattes in Toronto and we know it can succeed here. Proper food, snacks, and drinks are an important factor too, but to this point we've only been able to offer in a very limited fashion. We are now seeking to remedy this.

Why The Gamer's Grind isn't a Board Game Cafe Now

The following is a description of the events which prevented our remodel from including the much needed café and why we were forced to relocate. If this is not relevant or of interest to you feel free to skip ahead.

Our original intention was for The Gamer's Grind to be a board game café from the start. But we were not able to implement the highly important café portion. The main reason was because the landlord failed to honor the agreements made in the lease regarding tenant allowance. This, along with other minor issues forced us to push forward as best we could, but we finally had to relocate. We also had to liquidate all of the café equipment we had purchased but were never able to put to use.

Unfortunately, our current form and location are not sustainable. We are still open for now, but will likely shut down in a month in an effort to start a reboot as a proper board game café (even if we are not funded here).

To avoid similar issues this time around, we will do the following:

We will not enter any agreement requiring major building upgrades that are not funded up front by the landlord. The space we choose will have to be readily suitable for a café that’s in full regulatory compliance.

The location would have to be in an area with an active nightlife and would have previously included a café, coffee house or sandwich shop so major remodeling won’t be necessary. We have already scouted and found a couple of suitable locations.

Our Goal for this Campaign

We are seeking funding to do a complete reboot of The Gamer's Grind. Full funding will cover the cost to move into a higher profile location, re-purchase the required café equipment, including a commercial brewer, an espresso machine, blender, a refrigerated serving cooler for sandwiches and paninis.

It will also cover our initial operating capital for expenses like hiring professional individuals experienced in putting together the café side of the business.

What We Have Already

We already have the necessary tables, chairs, counters, shelves, retail inventory, office equipment, drink carts, a popcorn popper, over 580 games on the "Wall of Games", and all the basic equipment you would expect a small store/business to have.

Why Support a Board Game Café?

A board game café offers the community a unique entertainment destination. It presents a new social option for friends and family to hang out and have fun in a relaxed and inviting environment. It's also home to an extensive library of games; you’re pretty much guaranteed to find something you’ve never tried before.

Of course, we also have a large number of valuable Perks to encourage your contribution and make this all possible. A board game café is also a way to try new games before you buy. Many of our regular customers have taken full advantage of that benefit.

When We Reach Our Goal

In addition to growing our Wall of Games to at least double its current size of almost 600 titles, we will secure a new location, purchase all the necessary café equipment, bring in a knowledgeable individual with past experience putting together a coffee house/café, and install all necessary shelving and furnishings.

If We Surpass Our Goal to a $80k Level

We will get a larger location and purchase a high end dedicated RPG table.

If (by some craziness) we Surpass Our Goal to a $300k Level

Once established and operating smoothly we will soon after look to other cities for a second location. Top contributor opinions will be given first consideration. Every $300k level we hit we will consider yet another location. This is not likely to say the least but if it does that is what will happen.

Perks for Contributing

Local Perks:

For individuals local to the Sacramento area or if you choose to gift your perk to someone local, there are several Wall of Games passes and drink combination offers.

Local & Non Local Perks:

For both local and non-local contributors there are several options for game purchases of 40% off manufacturer suggested retail prices (MSRP).

 

Promo Card Perks: (This list will be updated as more promo items come in)

Promo Card Perks may include any 3 of the following random promo cards in no particular order: Aquarious Flux Cards, Hastur Flux Cards, Star Fluxx Button, The Resistance Merlin & Assassin cards, Belfort Guild Guild Promo Pack #1, Tsuro of the Seas promo pieces, D&D Board game Vierna Do'urden Drow Card, Catan Great River mini expansion, Dork Tower Poster (Dice plotting to kill you), Mini sample game of Spot it, Mini Sample Game of Reverse Charades Jr. Evil Baby Orphange Heinrich Himmler card and more on the way which will be added later.

NOTE: Promo card packs will be random but if you purchase this contribution level and contribute another amount we will let you pick one of the promo items (if it has not been spoken for) with the remaining 2 random. Contact us first to be sure it has not been spoken for.

NOTES on 40% Off game purchase Perks:

The vast majority of the games we carry or have access to are eligible for this offer. There might be a very tiny percentage of items that we would have to price at our cost to avoid losing money. This is not likely to come up often, but we want to mention that it is a rare possibility. The offer applies to any game we can acquire from our distributors.

Please also note that some of our normal in-store prices are 10-20% below Manufacture Suggested Retail Price (MSRP). The 40% discount is not off our marked prices, but from MSRP. This offer is non-transferable and can only be redeemed by the contributing individual. If shipped, it can only be shipped to the confirmed address of the contributor. Shipping and Taxes may apply.

In the case of shipping you can choose either UPS or USPS. Shipping will be an additional charge but we will only charge the cost of shipping. We will not up charge for shipping or add on any "handling" charges. Shipped orders will be placed by phone. Individuals claiming this perk that require shipping will have to provide a name, address and the last 4 digits of the credit card they will be using. Shipped orders will only be to the recorded address and individual. On the off chance we close down or down size we will be able to continue to honor this perk operating out of a smaller place that just processes orders.

Video Editing Services

For game designers and companies there are video editing services with professional voice over work for any kick starter or "how to play" videos in addition to having your games featured on our YouTube video series "After Play". We will consider non game designer or companies on this offer but please contact us first. Some samples of our work can be found on our "GamersGrind" YouTube channel http://www.youtube.com/user/GamersGrind. Specific examples include our shows "After Play" and "The Gamer's Grind Show". There are also some L5R Design Diaries, kick starter videos and some others. I have roughly 10 years of video production experience which includes working on live entertainment and news programs at a number of local television stations.

Other Ways to Contribute

Another way to contribute is by donating board games to The Wall. To see what we have currently, please visit www.thegamersgrind.com and click on the Wall of Games tab for our most recent list. If you’re local we may offer Wall of Game passes in exchange, based on the donation.

If we are Successful

If funding is successful, we pledge to "Pay it Forward" and at some point in the future and significantly help some other business the way we were helped. IndieGoGo and other similar sites offer the opportunity for people to help people and businesses, create jobs, and fulfill dreams. The "powers that be" appear too busy bickering with each other to much care, so it's up to us individuals to help change the world, one brick at time. Thank you so much for your support.

Short Summary
My Name is Ron Petersen and I started planning The Gamer's Grind back in early 2010. Funded with a small inheritance, our doors opened in March 2012. My intention was to use the tools left to me to build something unique and provide some much needed entertainment to our local community: a board game café!
What qualifies me to take on something so ambitious? I'm glad you asked.
I have a diverse background in retail and distributor sales as well as running a small business. I have experience with shipping and receiving, video production, working in the media. But most of all, I have a passion for people and games.
In researching our business plan I discovered a place called Snakes and Lattes that had just opened in Toronto Canada. They've enjoyed great success, doubling their store's size and acquiring a liquor license. Their success shows us that the board game café model clearly works.
Our Mission and Vision
Our mission is to provide the ultimate game night experience. We believe every type of game is valuable and can bring friends and family together to share laughs and enjoy each other’s company. We intend to keep building up the wall of games to have an extensive library. We want every type of gamer to have a large variety of options to choose from in a comfortable and fun environment, even the pickiest of game enthusiasts. Our mission is also to open people's eyes to just how many games are out there. The more casual or occasional game player may only be aware of what one or two large corporations have to offer, but the game palette we offer is much more varied. But most importantly we want to offer a highly unique entertainment destination. This is still a new business model in North America, and that’s what makes it such a great opportunity!
What is a Board Game Café?
Board Game Cafes have been around for a while and are very popular in many Asian countries and some European countries, but hardly any exist in North America. Basically you take a café or coffee house, combine it with a large library of games to play, and throw in a small game store. People come in, pay a small amount and can play games as long as they like while enjoying the available food, snacks, and drinks. Some board game cafes charge by the hour, but we opted for a cover charge instead because we believe it’s more conducive to a relaxing and casual environment. It’s proven successful with Snakes and Lattes in Toronto and we know it can succeed here. Proper food, snacks, and drinks are an important factor too, but to this point we've only been able to offer in a very limited fashion. We are now seeking to remedy this.
Why The Gamer's Grind isn't a Board Game Cafe Now
The following is a description of the events which prevented our remodel from including the much needed café and why we were forced to relocate. If this is not relevant or of interest to you feel free to skip ahead.
Our original intention was for The Gamer's Grind to be a board game café from the start. But we were not able to implement the highly important café portion. The main reason was because the landlord failed to honor the agreements made in the lease regarding tenant allowance. This, along with other minor issues forced us to push forward as best we could, but we finally had to relocate. We also had to liquidate all of the café equipment we had purchased but were never able to put to use.
Unfortunately, our current form and location are not sustainable. We are still open for now, but will likely shut down in a month in an effort to start a reboot as a proper board game café (even if we are not funded here).
To avoid similar issues this time around, we will do the following:
We will not enter any agreement requiring major building upgrades that are not funded up front by the landlord. The space we choose will have to be readily suitable for a café that’s in full regulatory compliance.
The location would have to be in an area with an active nightlife and would have previously included a café, coffee house or sandwich shop so major remodeling won’t be necessary. We have already scouted and found a couple of suitable locations.

We are seeking funding to do a complete reboot of The Gamer's Grind. Full funding will cover the cost to move into a higher profile location, re-purchase the required café equipment, including a commercial brewer, an espresso machine, blender, a refrigerated serving cooler for sandwiches and paninis.
It will also cover our initial operating capital for expenses like hiring professional individuals experienced in putting together the café side of the business.
What We Have Already
We already have the necessary tables, chairs, counters, shelves, retail inventory, office equipment, drink carts, a popcorn popper, over 580 games on the "Wall of Games", and all the basic equipment you would expect a small store/business to have.

story:
What is Sandman: Escape From Dreamland

It's after lunch on a warm summers day. Martin is trapped in an important, although boring, meeting and is desperately trying to keep his eyes open. Slowly he nods off to sleep. Suddenly he "awakens" to find the Sandman, who informs him of his fate. Sandman has lost his power and they are both stuck. Help Martin regain the Sandman's power and escape dreamland. To do this you must run, jump, slide or otherwise traverse through various dreams to collect hourglasses - the source of Sandman's power. Guide Martin on the journey of a lifetime as you traverse surreal and wonderful dreamscapes using your epic platforming skills. Watch out for McCoy, Sandman's dastardly nemesis.

Sandman: Escape From Dreamland is a 3D platformer for PC. We designed this game to be similar to console style 3D platformers, because we feel this is a genre that the PC is somewhat lacking in at the moment.
 

Features and General Info

  • An Alpha version will be released to supporters by mid August. The alpha version will include 15 levels from 5 different worlds.
  • The final version of the game will feature over 80 levels, which are split between 16 different worlds and four other environments.
  • Not all levels are about platforming skill, some also feature some tough puzzles that will make you think.
  • Planned for completion by the end of January 2014.

 

Be a part of it

By supporting us in our endeavours to make this game you too become part of the team that makes a game happen.

  • Get the Alpha build of the game to test for bugs and, more importantly, what we call the fun factor.
  • Have your say, as you also gain access to our development forums to make your voices heard.
  • For major supporters (The forty (+10) Winks pack and above) we will be releasing exclusive preview levels demonstrating newly implemented features.

 


Who are we

A small game and simulation development company from Adelaide, Australia. We've been around for just over a year now and have previously been focussed on contract programming work for training simulators. For the last four months we have slowly been focussing more and more on creating Sandman. Now we believe that Sandman is now ready for the world to see and want to take the prototype we have and finish it.

What we need to do this

If you regularly look at crowdfunds for video games you will surely know that $10,000 is on the rather low end of the spectrum for funding games. How are we planning on completing Sandman with this funding? Easy. First of all our company consists of only two people. Secondly we already own all the necessary software licenses to create the game. Thirdly we already have large chunks of the game code complete. The funds go directly to cost of living expenses as we zerg out to complete the game as fast as possible, to the highest quality possible. Whilst $10,000 is enough to complete the basic version of the game we have designed many more features and mechanics, which will be introduced should we exceed our target. Stay tuned as we get closer to our goals as we will be announcing stretch goals and the features/extensions they contain.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're really keen for the game you can help more by spreading the word, whether it be through Facebook, Twitter or just regular chats around the water cooler. You could also vote for Sandman on Steam Greenlight.

story:
Eminus is a realistic Tactical FPS game. I started developing this game the same time I started learning game development. I have been working on it for about 8 months now, and I am releasing a FREE demo on Steam so you can see my progress so far, without spending any money. 

 

Official Discord

Download Free Demo(Click Here)

 

 

By doing this, I am sure that everyone will see the passion and time I have been putting into this game. Yes, there will be a few bugs etc in the demo, but its goal is to show you, what I was able to create in only a few months of learning and working on this game.

The reason I chose Indiegogo, is because even though I am creating my own codes etc, I will still need plenty of art assets to make Eminus as good as possible. More and better animations, more weapons, buildings and level designing tools are some of the things that I would like to buy to make the game exactly as I want it to be.

 

 

Many functions are already implemented in the game but if you play the demo you will realize that there is room for improvement. For example, I could use better bullet impact effects, blood particles, sound effects, animations for proper prone, lean, reload and much more.

These are things that I can easily add/change in the game once I have the assets I need.

The game is going to be released no matter what and I will do my best to give you the best experience I can.

 

 

Features that already exist in the game(for the free demo):

  • 5 Different Guns
  • 1 Forest map with multiple objectives
  • Standard+ AI
  • Binoculars
  • Compass
  • Stealth mechanics
  • Drivable Quadbike (not enabled in Demo)
  • Pickable Ammo, Medical bags, Sniper Rifle
  • And many small details such as: Bullet holes, bullet impact SFX etc.
  • Graphic & Sound Settings
     

 

Features that will be added in the full game:

 

  • 4 Large maps with multiple objectives-missions and different Biomes
  • More pickable and usable weapons
  • Advanced AI
  • More character animations such as Prone(Added), Lean(Added), Climb, Slide etc.
  • More gadgets such as Flashlights, NV Goggles and more
  • Pickable Weapon attachments
  • Easter Eggs
  • Possibly Co-op mod
  • And a well written story with plot twists that you won't expect.

 

 

Optimization:

Making the game run smooth for everyone is a top priority, so it is being worked constantly.

For those with some knowledge on the topic, here's an example of the LOD's distance settings, and a screenshot of how it looks in-game.

 

Stretched Goals:

 

  • 8.000$ - 2 Extra Maps (Locked)
  • 14.000$ - Zombie Campaign/2 Maps (Locked)
  • 20.000$ - Singleplayer Open World Survival Mode (Locked)
  • 30.000$ - Story Co-op mode (Locked)

story:
Introduction

Welcome to Antarra - a little mining planet on the outskirts of the Federation territories.

Prepare to be amazed by a fantabulous show full of rivalry and competition for the title of the best pilot, the winner of which will be granted the honor of joining the elite squad of Federation pilots.
Is there a better way to prove your worth than winning the biggest and the fastest race in this part of the universe? It will be the ultimate test of character, reflexes, resolve, technique and endurance (even against a direct rocket hit) for the best pilots this universe has ever known.
In a series of races including time-trials, head-to-head competition and elimination on five different planets in various environments and different conditions a new champion will rise...

 

  The Game

Our game is all about space races - fast and spectacular! The tracks run through jungles, deserts, ruins of ancient civilizations and even the ocean floor! The game was inspired by old games such as Mega Race, Star Wars Racer or Wipeout. However, we are not trying to clone any of these games, we would like to follow their examples, but also to confront them with our own vision of the genre, our own solutions and ideas.

Here are some of the features you will see in the game (some of them are already finished):

  • Tracks - 5 completely different planets, varying in climate and environments. Some are ideal for high-speed laps, while others are planned for fierce competition and shortcut hunting;
  • Vehicles along with their parameters that can be tuned and modified freely (speed, handling, shields);
  • Weapons - there will be several types of those; some of the races will require the pilots to use them to be the first on the finish line;
  • Power-ups -depending on the race mode, you will see useful pick-up items along the track;
  • Leader - each planet will have its local champion - beat him to win his vehicle;
  • Soundtrack - we have a custom soundtrack recorded for the game, every song highlights the unique character of each planet;
  • Free DLCs - we are planning to make several free DLCs that will add new vehicles and planets.

 

  About us

But let's get down to Earth, shall we?
We are a team of two guys called Ambiverse who want to fulfill their dream and create something different... than we usually do. We have decided to join our forces, combine our knowledge and create something unique.
We have set the bar quite high, but we felt it was the right thing to do. We have tested different things and solutions, gained new skills and finally decided to pick up this project.

One year later...

 

  What are we raising the funds for?

We have managed to finish most of the project by investing our own spare time, resources and skills. People often helped us just because they could - this is how we have received, for example, a license to use some of the fonts we needed. Eventually we hit a wall, a bigger technical issue, which has to be solved before we can release the title the way we want. We do not want to cut or resign from content we planned for the game, so after long talks and careful consideration of all our options, we are facing a critical choice - we can either hire one more person to help us polish the final product, or we can give up - which obviously is not an option. Unfortunately, our financial resources are limited and nobody (apart from us) will work for free.


  Thresholds

  • 1500€ - our main goal aims at hiring one more person to finish the game
  • 2000€ - would let us add additional content such as new tracks or vehicles to the game
  • 5000€ - would let us re-master the sounds and re-record them in a studio
  • 10000€ - means we could hire additional people and add a multiplayer mode


  What platforms are we targeting?

We dedicate our game to iOS with the target devices being iPhone 4 / iPod 4 / iPad 2 and better. UDK operates on these platforms with no additional extensions. We cannot guarantee ports into other platforms, but we are not ruling out ports into Android.

 

  How can you help?

Everyone can help. You can donate, give positive comment or constructive criticism, share the link to our site or anything else, really. If you have any questions, ideas or you simply want to know a bit more about us, send an e-mail to warp@ambiverse.pl. We'll try to respond to every e-mail we get.

 

  Summing it up

We hope we were able to share at least a fraction of our vision. Now we can't do much more than to promise you that we will do everything in our power to provide you with a great, enjoyable game that will meet your expectations.
If everything goes as we plan, we will release the game this year. Of course, there might be delays if something unexpected happens. We will regularly update you on the status of development and add new materials on our site.

Keep in touch!

The Game

Traitor is a first-person shooter game for mobile devices and tablets. The game tells the story of desperate renegade German Army officer and his plot against Hitler during World War II. Colonel Claus decide to become a hitman. The game emplies stealth, disguise, hand-to-hand assassinations.

The Plan

So far we have invested our own money developing and popularizing android version of the game.  We want to do the same for pc and ios, especially ipad.


If you are android user the android version is ready now, you can download and test it!

Download Test Version

Please leave us your views and comments so that we can refine our game-play and make a game you really love.

Why we need your support

With so much noise and content in the mobile gaming space, it is hard for new developers to reach fans. Help from a big company, means losing control of the project so we are asking you.

Risks & Challenges

No crowdfunding campaign is entirely without risks, but the ones here aren't too big. However, a project like this one can suffer delays for a number of reasons.

Spread the Word!
  • Make some noise - word of mouth is still the best promotion!
  • Indiegogo has share tools - use them!

Don’t hesitate to talk about this project to others around you and to share it on social networks.  If you follow blogs, celebrities or press journalists, ask them to take a look and to talk about the project.

story:
Send Domo to Evo!

Hello!

My name is Thor, but most people in the FGC just know me as Domo.

I've been in the FGC for about 4 years now, and since then I've become pretty well known in the Skullgirls community as a pretty good player.

I'm making this IGG campaign to help get me to the largest fighting game tournament on earth: Evo.

Going to Evo has been a dream of mine ever since I first heard of it, but times have been very tough for my family's business. We can't afford hiring other employees or having salaries for ourselves, so a trip to Las Vegas is impossible for me right now.

How you can change that 

Donate!

The only thing keeping me from making Guitalex mad at my Double (in person this time!) is money.

Here's what your donations will be covering

  • Food for the entire trip- $100
  • Entry fee- $90
  • Plane tickets- $260
  • Hotel- $380

 

 

Why this means so much to me

Fighting games are more then just a hobby for me. They're one of the only things that really get me motivated these days, and going to tournaments are what I look forward to most in the year.

Sadly, I was unable to go to NWM5 (the primary major in Washington) this year, as I was recovering from having my wisdom teeth taken out just 3 days before the tournament. So going to Evo is my last chance for competing in a major tournament for the entire year.

In the four years I've been playing fighting games, I've met some awesome people, and made some invaluable friends. Going to Evo for me is a chance to meet some of those people in person, and test the skills I've worked so hard to gain over the years.

 

 What's in it for you?

Here's some of the perks for donating!

Painwheel/Double tutor

$10 gets you a 2 hour training session for Painwheel or Double, and a ft10 afterwards to help you further learn the characters.

Custom Arcade Stick art

For $35 I'll make you some one of a kind custom arcade stick art. You give me a theme, and I'll make it happen.

Heres some examples of my work

Mystery gift

$50 gets you a random manga, anime dvd, or figurine from my collection. It could be one of the new Evangelion movies, it could be a large Ghost in the Shell book , or it could even be an unopened Gundam kit!

HIGH-FIVE WONDERLAND *0*

 $80 gets you all of the above, make that ft10 into a ft30, and you get AS MANY HIGH-FIVES YOU COULD EVER POSSIBLY WANT from me at Evo!

Kinda dumb? YEP. But hey man, whats more valuable than high-fives?NOTHING.

 

Can't donate? You can still help!

A lot of people can't afford to donate anything, but you can still help me by spreading the word and posting a link to this page on Twitter, Facebook, and any other social networking site.

story:
UPDATE
 
We're now on Steam Greenlight! Come and vote for us!
 
 

We've been working on Pengame since 2007, only as a hobby. Then this year we erased everything and started from scratch - this time not just as a hobby project, but something we'd like to release eventually.

Pengame is a side scrolling shoot ’em up, with platforming elements. The combat is going to be fast paced, and skill based, involving different types of weapons, combo based melee attacks, an RPG-like skill tree and of course bullet time.

All graphics are hand drawn and animated frame by frame, giving the game a nice minimalistic aestethic. According to the plot everything was drawn by a 16 years old kid in his book during a boring class.Therefore initially we wanted the game to look like something anyone could draw... Well, our artists got a bit carried away there, so the game actually looks like it could have been drawn by anyone with the talents and expertise of a professional graphic designer. :)

The enemies are somewhat grotesque and nightmarish. Similar to the stuff we doodled in our high school years. Mechanical nodding rhinos, giant snails with cannons on their back, little cute demons playing electrical guitars, giant irish thugs with a can of beer in their hand - anything you can imagine, but probably wouldn't!

The level design is just as twisted as the enemies in looks. Some parts of the scenery will actually turn hostile to the player (like the Big Ben, who will try to kill Stickman, when he attempts to stop the watch at five o'clock, so everyone in London would go home and have a tea, leaving the city empty...).

The levels are going to be large, fairly open, freely explorable, with general directions on what the player should do (but with a few options on how he should do them).

There was this 16 years old kid, who hated school. Imagine that. He just kept doodling in his exercise book during class, creating a wonderful world. The doodles were happy and free. But everything changed, when the kid drew the Teacher, the most notoriously evil character any of the doodles have ever seen.

The Teacher corrupted the inhabitants of the book quickly, turning them into mindless minions of hers. Only a couple of them managed to hide, but none had the courage to fight back.

The Kid seeing the corruption drew four warriors to defeat the Teacher and restore order in the book, but they all failed, and got corrupted themselves. There is no other option, the Kid drew Number Five, a stick figure - this is his turn to try and save the world... Well, that one book, really, but it's a quite big one!



Number Five (#5) or Stickman is our main protagonist. Since he is only made out of simplistic lines and dots he is extremely agile. His abilities are tied with his minimalistic form, meaning he is able to adapt and endure. His predecessors (#1 - #4) were all big, strong drawings with various abilities (Time traveling, super-bullettime, extreme intelligence etc.), but with various weaknesses as well. #5 was created with no powers, but with no weaknesses!

The Kid takes up the role of the Narrator commentating on your actions. Unfortunately #5 isn't really the strong, silent type either, so you may expect him to have an opinion about the Kids choice of words.

A stickman needs his epic to be well written, not ruined by some 16 years old bugger, who probably knows nothing about literature!
 

The game will be fully voice acted. Lots of indie games don't have any, or have terrible voice acting, because that's a typical thing to save some money on. In our case the voice acting is the most important part of presenting the story to the player, so getting quality voice actors is a must. You can check out our Voice over documentation to get the idea.

What we get

Your support will help us to:

  • Work on Pengame full time (maybe hire some extra help).
  • Get an original soundtrack.
  • Get quality sound effects and voice actors.
  • Promote the game.

What you get

Most importantly the game - supporting us will act as a preorder (with any preorder bonuses we may come up until the release). The game on release will cost around 10 USD (not decided yet); but pledgeing now will get a copy for you for 5 USD (or even less if you grab the Early bird limited reward).

Some of the higher tier rewards will give you the chance to leave a mark in the game - like adding a short message that will come up as part of the scenery (since the game takes place in a book it'll blend in perfectly), or coming up with a new enemy type (abilities and looks as well). For obvious reasons though we have to limit these rewards. First-come, first-served.

In case we raise more

We'll be able to work on a multiplayer component (coop and PvP, including local splitscreen and online multiplayer). We would not postpone the release of the game in this case, but release the multiplayer as a free DLC a little bit later down the line.

Also more money would make it possible to port the game to other platforms (at this point we're only thinking about xbox 360, but it's only a matter of resources of course). In case we get enough pledges we'll add copies of Pengame for Xbox 360 (or any other platforms) to the list of rewards as well.

You know the drill - If you got too much money give it to us and we'll <3 you. If you barely got any money give it to us anyway and we'll seriously fricking LOVE you!

Or alternatively, if you honestly haven't got any money, just tell your friends about our project, share it on facebook, twitter, reddit, via e-mail, regular mail, make a cardboard sign of it and take it down the street, whatever you can think of! (Note that sharing our project via social media will also help us get featured here on IndieGoGo!)

If you happen to have any ties to gaming sites or blogs that might be interested in doing a story about our game and our campaign, please let them know about us!

Thank you!

We always wanted to have a comprehensive tool to channel our ideas in a fast and fun way without having to resort to several softwares, from there the idea of ​​golden8bits was born. A development environment for everything. We do not aim to compete with big development engines, but give the possibility to quickly create a sketch, mockup of a pixelart 8bits style game. We already have a beta of the software that only needs now the interface to create the music and sound fx, the system to generate the cartridges and load the cartridges. With the 5 thousand dollars raised we can finish the development of these topics mentioned above.

story:
Do you think you have what it takes to survive the zombie horde? Come on out and camp with us to prove your mettle!
 
The Texas Zombiefest Invitational Game is a weekend long game of HvZ. Hosted at Camp Woodlake in Brownwood, Texas by the Texas Tech Zombie Raiders student organizations.  The game is free to play, but payment is required for on-site accommodations.  This includes a place to sleep for two nights, 3 meals, and evening entertainment.  See specific options on right.

For more information on the event, see our website: http://greywindevents.wix.com/texaszombiefest
 
 
PLEASE READ ALL OF THE INFORMATION BELOW BEFORE REGISTERING.

What is HvZ?

Humans vs. Zombies is a game of tag normally played on college campuses. Participants are required to wear a bright green bandana around their arm or on their head to identify them as being part of the game and to differentiate whether they are human or zombie.  Participants start as humans and defend themselves from zombie players using foam dart blasters (Nerf, Air Zone, etc.) or socks to “stun” them.  Once tagged a human player becomes a zombie; thus creating a fight for human survival (or zombie domination) for the duration of gameplay.

Due to the limited space available for this event, registration is limited to 120 participants.

 

More information can be found at:
http://humansvszombies.org/

Why We Need You!

As a Student Organization attempting to run our first invitational event, we need to secure funding for the event in advance to ensure that we can get this event off the ground!  You can help us make this possible by registering to play or donating funds towards the event.

Why are we crowdfunding this event through IndieGoGo and using it for registration and reserving player accommodations?

  • It protects you. If we don't make the funding goal needed to run this event, the money is immediately returned to you.
  • It protects us.  It ensures that we have the minimum funding needed to run this event, so we don't have to worry about refunding everyone their money or dealing with additional fees or financial losses. It also allows us to make sure we have the money needed to pay for the event ahead of time.
  • IndieGoGo allows us to set the exact number of spots available for each type of accommodation so it will only accept payment for the space that we have.

 

Donations will help us to pay for:

  • Camp fees and deposits.
  • Deposits and payments for events.
  • Building costs of game props and other key pieces for use in the game’s storyline.

This is a fixed funding campaign, if we do not reach our goal, all money will be returned to registrants and the event will be canceled. Help us out!

You can also submit donations via the $5  “Helping Out Anyway I Can” option on the right. Please do not submit donations via the accommodations options (unless you are planning to attend) as that will register you as a player for the weekend and a registration spot will be removed unnecessarily.

 

 

Registration

To register to attend the event, select your preferred accommodations for the event under the “Perks” headline at the right side of the page and submit your payment information.  The three options are to bring your own tent, stay in a platform tent, or stay in a screened in cabin.

We have accomodations for 100 players available on site, and can accomodate a maximum of 120 players total.  If our accomodations are full and/or you would like to stay off-site, you must contact us through out website to make sure you are properly registered in our system. This will be first come, first serve.

*Note: All players must register wether they are onsite or offsite (if you are going to stay offsite, once you email us, we will confirm your registration, do not register on indiegogo). All players staying offsite will need to leave the property by 8pm each night. See the website for more information.

The $5 option does not reserve anything for the weekend and is only for charitable donations. If you would like to donate more, but will be unable to attend, please shoot us an email and we will be glad to work with you on some "sponsor" benefits.

 

 Elgible Players: For our first year, players are required to be 18+ years of age and enrolled at a university (however, if you are not a current student, please contact us and we can make some exceptions if space allows). 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can make it out to this years invitational, however, if you are interested in helping us out monetary wise, we are always looking for people to help us spread the word so that we can continue to throw events each semester.



We thank you all so much for your help in making this amazing event happen!

story:
The Plot of Legend of Animana

 

The land of Animana is a calm, yet peaceful land. Things were always about talking problems through and solving them quickly. Not all things are what it seems, though! An evil wizard by the name of Nagaim decided to use his evil wizard powers to curse the land! By doing this, he made it to where the land had went to war and learned what it was like. Every single person is now possessed! The main characters are "immune" to this curse, as they were visiting another land which was exactly no different than their own. Their own parents, friends, and family are now alive and aggressive. How will the three of them work together to battle the evil wizard Nagaim?!

 

About Me

Hi, I'm Anna!

Some of you may know me as Gasai Yuno or Anna. Ever since my dream of becoming an English major fell through, I spend most of my time studying game design and writing. 

As some of you may know I wish to make an RPG Maker Game inspired by various anime and manga series.

 

Things I Need

1 or More RPG Maker VX Ace license to give to team members who'd like to help, but cannot buy their own license (70-80 dollars USD) 

High quality art (Prices vary, but looking to spend 100-150 on GOOD art)

Paying Artists / Graphics Artists / Etc 

Plus More

What Backers Get

Backers get the COMPLETE game when it is launched

Early Bird Access to exclusive private forums just for the backers. This is where you discuss the game, give the team members ideas, and all the other good stuff.

Concept Art - Stuff that was sketeched and drawn for us, but isn't used in the final product

FAQ

 

Q: When will the official forums be up? When will we see an actual Facebook page for it?

A: The website and forum will be up within the next few weeks or two. A Facebook page will be made very soon when we actually start work.

 

Q: Why no screenshots?

A: The game hasn't been made yet. We will post a buttload of screenshots as we make the game. You're still welcome to donate!

 

Q: Why no video of the game?

A: Read above

 

Q: Why should I donate to you?

A: I have a team of people who will help me design the game via RPG Maker VX Ace. I have experience dealing with, and handling the general public. We are all avid fans of old school RPGs like Final Fantasy, Chrono Trigger, and many others.
story_txt:
The Plot of Legend of Animana
 
The land of Animana is a calm, yet peaceful land. Things were always about talking problems through and solving them quickly. Not all things are what it seems, though! An evil wizard by the name of Nagaim decided to use his evil wizard powers to curse the land! By doing this, he made it to where the land had went to war and learned what it was like. Every single person is now possessed! The main characters are "immune" to this curse, as they were visiting another land which was exactly no different than their own. Their own parents, friends, and family are now alive and aggressive. How will the three of them work together to battle the evil wizard Nagaim?!
 
About Me
Hi, I'm Anna!
Some of you may know me as Gasai Yuno or Anna. Ever since my dream of becoming an English major fell through, I spend most of my time studying game design and writing. 
As some of you may know I wish to make an RPG Maker Game inspired by various anime and manga series.
 
Things I Need
1 or More RPG Maker VX Ace license to give to team members who'd like to help, but cannot buy their own license (70-80 dollars USD) 
High quality art (Prices vary, but looking to spend 100-150 on GOOD art)
Paying Artists / Graphics Artists / Etc 
Plus More
What Backers Get
Backers get the COMPLETE game when it is launched
Early Bird Access to exclusive private forums just for the backers. This is where you discuss the game, give the team members ideas, and all the other good stuff.
Concept Art - Stuff that was sketeched and drawn for us, but isn't used in the final product
FAQ
 
Q: When will the official forums be up? When will we see an actual Facebook page for it?
A: The website and forum will be up within the next few weeks or two. A Facebook page will be made very soon when we actually start work.
 
Q: Why no screenshots?
A: The game hasn't been made yet. We will post a buttload of screenshots as we make the game. You're still welcome to donate!
 
Q: Why no video of the game?
A: Read above
 
Q: Why should I donate to you?
A: I have a team of people who will help me design the game via RPG Maker VX Ace. I have experience dealing with, and handling the general public. We are all avid fans of old school RPGs like Final Fantasy, Chrono Trigger, and many others.
